back_matter.text: Umehara Fujio⁎ 2 2 Kagoshima University, Kagoshima, JapanThe objective of this study was to investigate the role of human Tlymphotropic virus-type I (HTLV-I) infection in patients with sporadic inclusion body myositis (sIBM) from endemic area in Japan.We have examined the twelve patients with inclusion body myositis associated with HTLV-I infection. The clinical features were consistent with sIBM. Anti-HTLV-I antibodies were present in the serum of all the patients. The muscle biopsies showed endomysial T cell infiltration with rimmed vacuoles, deposits of phosphorylated tau, abnormal filaments in the nuclei and cytoplasm of the muscle fibers, all diagnostic of IBM. The muscle fibers expressed major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class-I antigens and were invaded by CD8+ cells and CD4+ cells. In a single patient with human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-A2, in situ HLA-A⁎0201/Tax11-19-pentamer staining showed the pentamer-positive cells surrounding the muscle fibers. Double staining of immuno-gold silver staining (IGSS) and polymerase chain reaction in situ hybridization (PCR-ISH) revealed that HTLV-I proviral DNA was localized on helper-inducer T cells, but not on muscle fibers. HTLV-I proviral loads in peripheral blood mononuclear cell (PBMCs) from each patient were comparable to those seen in HTLV-I associated myelopathy (HAM)/tropical spastic paraparesis (TSP).This study suggests that HTLV-I infection may be one of the causes of sIBM, as has been reported in human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) infection. Herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is a rare disease affecting young children as well as adults due to infection with herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1). HSV-1 is a nearly ubiquitous virus commonly infecting humans however most do not develop HSE, suggesting that children with HSE possess an underlying genetic susceptibility to HSV-1. These patients are otherwise healthy and able to mount a normal adaptive immune response to HSV-1, pointing to the likelihood that they harbor an unidentified form of primary immunodeficiency disease affecting their innate immune response to HSV-1 infection. We have recently identified the first two genetic etiologies of HSE, autosomal recessive UNC93B deficiency and autosomal dominant TLR3 deficiency, validating our hypothesis. The goal of this study was to use a candidate gene approach to identify other gene(s) involved in HSE by cellular and immunological phenotyping.

back_matter.text: The cellular and immunological phenotype is focused on one of the major components of antiviral innate immunity, namely, the production of and response to type I interferons (IFNs). Patients with mutations in UNC93B and TLR3 show reduced production of type I IFNs after viral and double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) stimulation, revealing a specific UNC93B-TLR3-IFN pathway as relevant to HSE immunity. We have identified at least two other patients among our cohort of HSE patients with reduced production of type I IFN following viral and dsRNA activation for further genetic investigation using a candidate gene approach. We have excluded UNC93B and TLR3 deficiencies in these patients based on sequence analysis suggesting the existence of mutations in genes other than those we have already identified. Further immunological testing revealed that these patients' fibroblasts showed a specific decrease in interferon regulatory factor-3 (IRF3) dimerization consistent with the lack of IFN production. Sequencing and expression of all known genes in this critical pathway are in progress under the assumption that a mutation lies in one of these genes. Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease thought to be initiated by an autoimmune Th1 and Th17 response specific to antigens of the central nervous system. Contrary to this, recent data suggest that neurodegenerative mechanisms are primary triggers of some forms of MS. In this scenario, a major role could be played by the release of potential self-antigens from dying oligodendrocytes (ODCs).To test this hypothesis we developed a mouse model (MOGiCre/ iDTR) that allows us to selectively initiate ODC cell death in an inducible manner by transgenic expression of a diphtheria toxin receptor in ODCs and peripheral injection of diphtheria toxin (DT). Injection of DT resulted in pronounced demyelination, and was clinically characterized by ataxia, tremor, development of a hunchback and complete paralysis. Due to the massive demyelination at the peak of the disease a dramatic neuronal degeneration was observed. Surprisingly, many of the diseased mice recovered completely even after complete hind limb paralysis. The later may be a result of an accumulation of ODC precursors in the demyelinated brain areas, as observed by us. None of the sick animals showed signs of classical EAE or brain infiltration of immune cells, although the animals showed an activation of microglia followed by strong gliosis. Thus, we investigated whether and under which conditions dying ODCs release antigens that can prime T-cell responses towards myelin. Injection of CFSE-labeled, MOG-reactive Tcell receptor transgenic cells showed no or only moderate T-cell proliferation after ablation of ODCs. In addition, release of antigen by dying ODCs did not lead to tolerance induction.We conclude that factors in addition to ODC-death lead to the neurological symptoms observed in EAE, and that at least in mice, dying of ODCs does not contribute to EAE induction or even tolerance.
